answers.answer: Hi!Yes, this is a tough situation. Anti-seizure medications usually help control diabetes, not aggravate it. I am not sure what medications your husband is on, nor can suggest a change on net. You can talk to his treating doctor in Vegas and describe his blood sugar reports and BP records and ask their advice. Maybe they can fax across all his reports to your neurologist in home town. Meanwhile consult a diabetes specialist and try controlling his sugar.   Take care!

question: My husband is 49 and has been very healthy. In March he was diagnosed with a bleed on the right side of the brain and flown to Vegas.  The first surgery was done and he was released.  He was then sent back to Vegas a week later because there was more blood. After this surgery he developed a seizure.  His left arm starting batting back and forth.  He was also disagnosed with high blood pressure and diabetes.  They released him on 3 antizeisure meds and told me to follow up with a nuerologist which we have.  We have seen this doctor here in Kingman twice now and had a EEG.  He feels that my husband is taking too many meds for this but won't due anything until he receives complete medical records from the hospital in Vegas.  Meanwhile, the sugar level is high and his general doctor is saying that the anit seizure meds could be causing this.  What are we to do?
title: Blood on brain, diabetes, high blood pressure and seizure meds...ugh
